image.altText: A picture of a Corruption and Crime Commission report into 'serious misconduct risks in a housing authority project'

items.synopsis: WA's Corruption and Crime Commission finds the state's Department of Communities lost tens of millions of taxpayer dollars after buying shares in a private company.

title.children: WA government's 'disaster' investment in company costs taxpayers more than $30 million

image.altText: A composite image of a man and woman wearing black

items.synopsis: The court heard there is "significant suspicion" around the cash, with concerns it is linked to an outlaw motorcycle gang.

title.children: Perth racing figure Kellie Kersley jailed for possessing almost half a million dollars of suspicious cash

image.altText: A man and woman stand in front of plants, they are looking directly towards the camera

items.synopsis: Jono and Jodie Reindl said changes at the Joondalup Health Campus since their baby died on the day she was born did not go far enough to prevent future healthcare failures.

title.children: Parents fight for better care as WA coroner finds death of baby Ashlee 'preventable'

image.altText: A well dressed woman arrives at court

items.synopsis: Helen Mary Rosamond embezzled millions from the NAB to fund a life of opulence between 2013 and 2017, including luxury holidays, business-class flights, and a 50th birthday party that cost $70,000.

title.children: 'Breathtaking in its audacity': Woman who embezzled millions from NAB jailed for 15 years

image.altText: A picture of the Collie electric vehicle charging station in Western Australia

items.synopsis: The proponent says regional WA needs a reliable EV charging network to help facilitate the uptake of electric vehicles.

title.children: WA council rejects offer to have EV charging stations installed in town

image.altText: Two women wearing work attire walking past the Reserve Bank of Australia offices in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Australia's unemployment rate surprises experts by dipping back to 3.5 per cent, with almost 33,000 extra people gaining jobs last month.

title.children: RBA's 'narrow path is widening': The jobs boom continues as all eyes turn back to inflation

image.altText: A woman wearing a red scarf looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Maria Barclay was just 17 years old when she enlisted in the Australian Defence Force and has told the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide serving among very few women in the military has had traumatising consequences.

title.children: 'I didn't have a voice': Ex-servicewoman tells commission of feeling isolated after sexual assault

image.altText: A woman with brown short hair sits behind a microphone

items.synopsis: The senior bureaucrat who oversaw the rollout of the Robodebt scheme is suspended without pay after the royal commission found she did "nothing of substance" after discovering illegalities.

title.children: Top bureaucrat behind Robodebt suspended from $900k job

image.altText: A police officer stands in front of a police car.

items.synopsis: New Zealand police say the 24-year-old had no licence for the shotgun he used to carry out the attack, and that he had a history of family violence.

title.children: Man who killed two at Auckland construction site had no gun licence, NZ police confirm

image.altText: The entrance to a school.

items.synopsis: Parents in a regional WA town accuse the education department of neglecting their school, as a new principal begins the term without any students following a mass exodus.

title.children: This school has no students after parents, fed up with 'getting no support', send kids elsewhere

image.altText: A close up of an unidentified rusted metal object

items.synopsis: With a rocket part that washed up on a WA beach now under lock and key at a "secret" location, governments are in talks over what will happen to it, while experts warn of more space junk to come.

title.children: With WA's mystery space junk secured, there are calls to put it on permanent display

image.altText: Andre Viljoen in his homemade jet flying above Tuross Head

items.synopsis: It started with model aeroplanes as a teenager. Then he piloted gliders. Now, retired dentist Andre Viljoen has built his own jet aircraft to see Australia's best sights.

title.children: Retiree's bird's-eye view of Australia from his homemade jet aircraft

image.altText: A dirt-coloured cylinder is seen at the bottom of a dirt pit. Earthworks have been conducted around it, establishing walls.

items.synopsis: An unexploded, 220kg World War II-era bomb on Nauru has been defused by Australian and Nauruan authorities after it was discovered earlier this month during earthworks operations.

title.children: WWII bomb defused on Nauru after state of disaster declared, people evacuated

image.altText: A close-up shot of a bottle of mustard being squeezed onto a butterflied sausage on bread and onions, with tomato sauce on top.

items.synopsis: While a sausage in white bread is a staple of community events, leaders in Djarindjin, north of Broome, are putting their foot down by demanding healthier options be served.

title.children: No sausage sizzles, no fried takeaway as ban puts remote town on healthier path

image.altText: A middle-aged white woman with short grey hair. She is standing by a door, wearing a blue sweater

items.synopsis: Jenny Moncur's husband Royce died in 2014 after being diagnosed with cancer. Almost a decade later, she was still being contacted about his Telstra account.

title.children: 'Like a Monty Python skit': Telstra 'harassed' Jenny for nine years over her dead husband's account

image.altText: a vote no pamphlet featuring indigenous artwork

items.synopsis: An Indigenous artist and elder is "disgusted" that a painting he composed of Uluru has been reappropriated to help spread misinformation about the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'Vote No' to Voice to Parliament flyers peddling false claims under investigation by election watchdog

image.altText: Three donkeys in a line

items.synopsis: Biosecurity groups in Western Australia are concerned a halt to government-run aerial culling operations will allow feral animal numbers to get out of control in pastoral areas.

title.children: Fears camel, horse and donkey numbers could spike without government aerial shooters in WA

image.altText: A man wearing a shirt with Australian sits on top of a horse while hugging it

items.synopsis: Commonwealth Games athletes are not the only ones facing a devastating blow, with a bid to bring the 2027 Special Olympics World Games to Perth in danger of failing unless funding is secured within weeks.

title.children: Jordan's connection with his horse is like 'father and son'. But his hopes of showing it off are hanging in the balance

image.altText: A casket in a cathedral

items.synopsis: The former member for Hotham has been remembered by those who knew him as a great Australian, and a "courageous son" of the Labor movement.

title.children: Anthony Albanese labels Simon Crean 'man of decency' as mourners bid farewell to the former Labor leader

image.altText: A glass pipe, used for smoking the drug ice, sits on a bench.

items.synopsis: A Cooma man who stabbed his friend more than 15 times during a paranoid drug-fuelled rage on an isolated Snowy Mountains road in 2021, has been sentenced to 24 years behind bars for his murder.

title.children: Court hears of horrific final moments of man’s life before 'brutal' murder by laughing, meth-crazed killer

image.altText: A man holds a phone up in air, he wears grey jumper, work pant and boots. He stands on a stone fence facing a roof

items.synopsis: Lynton Barrett wants to know if the phone coverage will improve at his Lameroo farm before he invests more than $10,000 in mobile boosters.

title.children: For nearly a decade, this farmer has had to stand on a fence to make a phone call and he's fed up

image.altText: man in suit with necklace

items.synopsis: Two days after his deputy rejected the idea, Tom Tate says the tourist strip can turn "Victoria's lemon ... into lemonade".

title.children: Gold Coast mayor says city prepared to host '26 Commonwealth Games, with provisos

image.altText: Raghe Mohammed Abdi smiles a the camera. He wears a school uniform consisting of a maroon jacket and tie, and a blue shirt.

items.synopsis: The 22-year-old was fatally shot by officers on the side of a Queensland motorway after he came toward them holding a knife.

title.children: Man who killed elderly Brisbane couple before being shot by police was 'absolutely radicalised', inquest hears

image.altText: An Australian female road cyclists stands with the national flag behind her while wearing her Comm Games gold medal.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has rejected suggestions by Victoria's opposition leader that the federal government did not allocate money for the Commonwealth Games in the last budget because they knew they were going to be cancelled.

title.children: Federal government did not get pre-budget warning of Games cancellation, Albanese says

image.altText: A black-and-white close-up of a gaunt and harrowed-looking man with a stetson hat and a cigarette in his mouth.

items.synopsis: There is only one IMAX 1570 film print of the new-release epic in the southern hemisphere, and the only two projectionists trained to show it are treating the spool like "liquid gold".

title.children: Only two people in Australia know how to show Christopher Nolan's Oppenheimer in its full IMAX glory

image.altText: General manager Tricia Ong packing dog treats.

items.synopsis: Australians took to online shopping with gusto during the pandemic, but now they need to brace for rising costs as deliveries become much more expensive.

title.children: Online retailers 'hit left, right and centre' as shipping costs surge and demand falls

image.altText: A photo of Travis King in army uniform, standing in front of an American flag. He is a black man  in his 20s with dark eyes.

items.synopsis: Private Travis King had served time for assault in a South Korean prison and was due to board a flight back to the US when he fled the airport and joined a civilian tour to the demilitarised border village of Panmunjon.

title.children: US soldier had served time for assault in South Korean prison before crossing to North Korea

image.altText: Marnus Labuschagne holds the bridge of his nose in frustration while walking off the field

items.synopsis: Predicted rain means this critical fourth Ashes Test could be compressed into three days' worth of play, only adding to the frustration of Australia's batting performance on day one.

title.children: Australia can't close the door on England as Ashes remain alive in Test forced into fast-forward

image.altText: Soldiers tend a stationary cannon underneath camouflage netting.

items.synopsis: An Australian man serving on the frontline with the Ukrainian International Legion is alleging that Australians, Ukrainians and other volunteers are being put in danger and threatened with repercussions for speaking out by some incompetent Ukrainian commanders.

title.children: 'It's a meat grinder': Aussie whistleblower claims some Ukrainian Legion commanders are putting soldiers in danger

image.altText: High speed car chase in Sydney crash

items.synopsis: Camera footage shows a car weaving in and out of traffic, hurtling through intersections, and driving on the wrong side of the road at high speeds.

title.children: Man and woman arrested after wild police chase through Sydney suburbs

image.altText: Telstra Shop signage outside Brisbane CBD store

items.synopsis: Telstra is the latest company to announce major job cuts, with nearly 500 employees to exit the company. It comes as Australia's unemployment rate fell in June to 3.5 per cent. Follow live.

title.children: Telstra axes nearly 500 jobs to 'remain competitive' as unemployment rate falls to 3.5pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has kept gaining throughout the trading day so far, up 0.2% to 7,338 points as of 1:15pm. (If you want live figures of the major ASX indices, head to the pinned post at the top of the page and expand it for a full quote list and charts.) Investors are still digesting the latest unemployment figures, and crucially, what it might been for interest rates ahead of the RBA's meeting next month. As Gareth has mentioned, some economists still think there's a red-hot chance of another hike or two coming our way from the central bank — but we will get a better picture when we get inflation data next Wednesday. Taking a look at the sectors, technology is the best performer, up 0.4%, with real estate close behind at 0.3%. Financials and consumer non-cyclicals are also up 0.1% each, while the rest of the sectors are in the red, with industrials and healthcare down 0.5% each. The top five performers so far: Mineral Resources +4.9% Flight Centre +4.1% Megaport +3.6% Ampol +2.9% Lendlease +2.9% And the worst performers so far today: Telix Pharmaceuticals -13.4% Northern Star Resources -5.4% Sayona Mining -2.8% BrainChip Holdings -2.5% Boral -2.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Modest gains on the ASX as investors mull latest jobs figures

children.content: The Australian share market has kept gaining throughout the trading day so far, up 0.2% to 7,338 points as of 1:15pm.
(If you want live figures of the major ASX indices, head to the pinned post at the top of the page and expand it for a full quote list and charts.)
Investors are still digesting the latest unemployment figures, and crucially, what it might been for interest rates ahead of the RBA's meeting next month.

As Gareth has mentioned, some economists still think there's a red-hot chance of another hike or two coming our way from the central bank — but we will get a better picture when we get inflation data next Wednesday.
Taking a look at the sectors, technology is the best performer, up 0.4%, with real estate close behind at 0.3%.
Financials and consumer non-cyclicals are also up 0.1% each, while the rest of the sectors are in the red, with industrials and healthcare down 0.5% each.
The top five performers so far:
Mineral Resources +4.9%
Flight Centre +4.1%
Megaport +3.6%
Ampol +2.9%
Lendlease +2.9%
And the worst performers so far today:
Telix Pharmaceuticals -13.4%
Northern Star Resources -5.4%
Sayona Mining -2.8%
BrainChip Holdings -2.5%
Boral -2.3%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The participation rate — which measures the number of people who are working or looking for work — was also down slightly in June, down from May's record high. It's now sitting at 66.8% — and Sally Auld from JBWere says it would be a reason why we've seen a drop in the unemployment rate. "The  participation rate measures the  number of people who are either  employed or actively looking for a job and the fact that was down 0.1% might have meant that in a month  where job demand or labour demand  was obviously pretty strong it  helped to push the unemployment rate lower," she said. "But I wouldn't get obsessed  with small moves either way in the participation rate. "I think the main thing is here is despite what we've seen, some of the softening of the leading indicators, the numbers are telling us the labour market remains very tight and very strong ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Participation rate also falls slightly to 66.8 per cent

children.content: The participation rate — which measures the number of people who are working or looking for work — was also down slightly in June, down from May's record high.
It's now sitting at 66.8% — and
Sally Auld from JBWere
says it would be a reason why we've seen a drop in the unemployment rate.

"The  participation rate measures the  number of people who are either  employed or actively looking for a job and the fact that was down 0.1% might have meant that in a month  where job demand or labour demand  was obviously pretty strong it  helped to push the unemployment rate lower," she said.
"But I wouldn't get obsessed  with small moves either way in the participation rate.
"I think the main thing is here is despite what we've seen, some of the softening of the leading indicators, the numbers are telling us
the labour market remains very tight and very strong

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's unemployment rate has dipped to 3.5%, with an estimated 33,000 extra people gaining jobs last month. Economists were generally tipping the unemployment rate to remain steady at 3.6% with the creation of around 15,000 jobs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Unemployment rate falls slightly to 3.5 per cent in June

children.content: Australia's unemployment rate has dipped to 3.5%, with an estimated 33,000 extra people gaining jobs last month.
Economists were generally tipping the unemployment rate to remain steady at 3.6% with the creation of around 15,000 jobs.

image.altText: Aerial view of a tank on a semi-trailer next to the burnt shell of a B-double truck.

items.synopsis: Both lanes of the Bruce Highway are now open, as investigators piece together the chain of events that led to a crash involving several caravans, large trucks and a US military tank.

title.children: Police 'flabbergasted' no lives lost in fiery crash involving US tank as highway reopens

image.altText: Copy of Shadows

items.synopsis: Women's football started with sell-out crowds in the 1920s, only to be banned a year later. Through five decades of darkness, football's pioneers carried the torch for future generations.

title.children: Out of the shadows: How women's football flourished after 50 years of darkness
